paper_metadata.title: Amyloidogenic and non-amyloidogenic transthyretin variants interact differently with human cardiomyocytes: insights into early events of non-fibrillar tissue damage
paper_metadata.extraction_summary: Extracted information on TTR variants V122I and T119M, including clinical significance, penetrance data, and functional studies.

patients.phenotype: late onset familial amyloid cardiomyopathy (FAC), resulting in congestive heart failure and death

individual_records.evidence_sentence: The most common TTR mutation worldwide is V122I which is found in 4% of African–Americans and produces late onset FAC, resulting in congestive heart failure and death.

functional_data.summary: V122I TTR variant is cytotoxic to human cardiac cells, generating superoxide species and activating caspase 3/7.

variants.additional_notes: V122I TTR is associated with significant cytotoxic effects in cardiomyocytes.
key_quotes: V122I TTR variant is cytotoxic to human cardiac cells.
Incubation of the human cardiomyocytes with V122I TTR but not with T119M TTR, generates superoxide species and activates caspase 3/7.

patients.phenotype: non-amyloidogenic variant, does not induce cytotoxicity

functional_data.summary: T119M TTR variant is stable and non-amyloidogenic, does not induce cytotoxicity in cardiomyocytes.

variants.additional_notes: T119M TTR is used as a control in functional studies.
key_quotes: the stable and non-amyloidogenic T119M TTR variant does not have such effects.

extraction_metadata.notes: All relevant data extracted from the main text.
